abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, and sustainability likely, although
            institutional development impacts are only modest. Among the
            lessons learned, it is highlighted that potential
            macroeconomic reforms, and privatization require an
            established technical capacity to achieve such reforms,
            based on an essential political commitment. This is
            exemplified by the experience of the joint implementation of
            this project, and the Third Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project, which showed that the combination of an adjustment
            operation, and of a capacity building operation, does
            provide satisfactory outcomes, while underscoring the
            importance of harmonized activities, to achieve micro, and
            macroeconomic reforms in parallel. Another lesson spells out
            the need to implement public awareness campaigns,
            irrespective of possible prolonged dialogues, which by
            themselves may not necessarily lead to measurable
            indicators, or outputs. Though understandably there is the
            temptation to move ahead with numerical targets for
            enterprises to be privatized (or liquidated), it is also
            true that the government's refusal to render public
            awareness, may in the end limit the overall scope of the
            program. Specifically, due to budget constraints on the
            Bank's side, both a follow-up in the judicial
            component, and public awareness were neglected; indeed, a
            regulatory seminar would have raised awareness to forward
            the utilities privatization, while the judiciary system
            remains a major cause for the vulnerability of the banking
            sector, particularly deterring private investments.
